author: morningstar.com
title: Biotech Shares Drop, Tempering Stock-Market Gains
text:
By Corrie Driebusch And Tommy Stubbington
Biotechnology shares tumbled on Monday, tempering broader stock-market gains, after Hillary Clinton targeted specialty drug makers in a tweet.
Shares climbed sharply in morning trading, but at one point were nearly flat due to weakness in biotechnology stocks.
Traders attributed the decline in the sector to a comment posted by Hillary Clinton on Twitter about how she will outline a plan on Tuesday to take on "price gouging" by certain specialty drug makers. Before the comment by the presidential hopeful, the Nasdaq Biotechnology Index was hovering around the flatline. Following Mrs. Clinton's remark, which referenced a New York Times article published Sunday that focused on a certain drug's sharp price increase, the biotech index started its tumble. The index ended 4.4% lower.
Major indexes recovered from their midday pullback in late afternoon trading, however, as the market shook off initial concerns.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended up 125.61 points, or 0.8%, at 16510.19, and the S&P 500 rose 8.94 points, or 0.5%, to 1966.97, after both indexes declined sharply on Friday. In early trading the Dow industrials had risen as much as 194 points before Mrs. Clinton's tweet. Following the tweet the index gave up all but seven points at its lowest level.
"Some stocks were getting hit a little in the morning, but when the tweet went out the selling was considerable," said Sahak Manuelian, a managing director at Wedbush Securities. He added that the sector fell on Friday, and entering Monday he expected biotech shares to lose some ground, but not this much. "Guys started selling first and asking questions later," he said.
Shares of biotechnology companies, one of the hottest segments of the stock market in recent years, tend to be volatile. In March 2014, biotech companies sold off and dragged the broad market lower following a congressional complaint about the high price of a Gilead Sciences Inc. Hepatitis C drug.
In 2015, the Nasdaq Biotechnology Index climbed more than 30% for the year through late July, as investors, enthused by new biotech drugs and potential treatments as well as some strong earnings growth, scooped up shares of the companies. But the segment then fell out of favor, tumbling more than 18% by late August.
The Nasdaq Biotechnology Index remains 12% higher for the year.
Besides the selloff in biotech companies, markets around the globe generally steadied Monday after the U.S. Federal Reserve's decision last week to keep interest rates at record lows sparked a global selloff amid fears about the fragile state of the global economy. Although rock-bottom rates have helped fuel years of rising stocks since the financial crisis, the Fed's reluctance to lift borrowing costs was seen as a reminder that growth in the U.S. and elsewhere remains vulnerable to a slowdown in China.
Some investors warned the Fed's decision and the uncertainty it brings has created a lasting overhang on stock markets.
"We're in for a period of choppy markets," said Julian Chillingworth, chief investment officer at Rathbone Brothers PLC, which manages GBP28.3 billion ($43.9 billion) in assets.
"People are now going to debate whether the Fed does or doesn't raise rates this year. With that uncertainty, markets will be focusing on the short term," he said.
In Europe, markets were mostly higher, encouraged by Alexis Tsipras's resounding win in Sunday's Greek election. Mr. Tsipras's re-election after agreeing a bailout deal may soothe tensions with European creditors that jolted markets during the summer.
"We are left with the same government that signed the [bailout] deal. The positive part of the outcome was the parties critical of Europe didn't really gain," said Thomas Wacker, head of credit research at UBS Wealth Management.
The Stoxx Europe 600 closed 0.9% higher, having fallen 1.8% in the previous session.
In Asia, most indexes fell as markets reacted to Friday's decline on Wall Street, the biggest one-day loss in two weeks.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng fell 0.7% and Australia's S&P/ ASX 200 lost 2%. China bucked the trend, with the Shanghai Composite closing 1.9% higher.
Japanese markets were closed for a holiday.
In currency markets, the dollar rebounded from its post-Fed-decision losses. The euro was recently 1.1% lower against the dollar at $1.1189. The dollar climbed 0.4% against the yen to Yen120.5190.
In commodities, crude oil rose 4.5% to $46.68 a barrel. Gold was down 0.5% at $1,133.10 a troy ounce.
Write to Corrie Driebusch at corrie.driebusch@wsj.com and Tommy Stubbington at tommy.stubbington@wsj.com
(END) Dow Jones Newswires
